column2: June the twenty-second
column4: with the ostensible purpose of going to see her aunt
column5: or some other connection

column8: whatever
column9: come forward
column10: so far

column13: after she left her mother’s door. * * * Now
column14: though we have no evidence that Marie Rogêt was in the land of the living after nine o’clock on Sunday
column15: June the twenty-second
column16: we have proof that
column17: up to that hour
column18: she was alive. On Wednesday noon
column19: at twelve
column20: a female body was discovered afloat on the shore of the Barrière du Roule. This was
column21: even if we presume that Marie Rogêt was thrown into the river within three hours after she left her mother’s house
column22: only three days from the time she left her home—three days to an hour. But it is folly to suppose that the murder
column23: if murder was committed on her body
column24: could have been consummated soon enough to have enabled her murderers to throw the body into the river before midnight. Those who are guilty of such horrid crimes choose darkness rather than light. * * * Thus we see that if the body found in the river was that of Marie Rogêt

column26: or three at the outside. All experience has shown that drowned bodies
column27: or bodies thrown into the water immediately after death by violence

column29: and it rises before at least five or six days’ immersion

column35: also
column36: whether the body would be so soon afloat
column37: even were it thrown in after having been dead two days. And
column39: it is exceedingly improbable that any villains who had committed such a murder as is here supposed
